headline.main: POSTINGS  |  RECENT ENTRIES FROM OUR BLOGS

docs.abstract: Paula Span The New Old Age blog notes studies showing that cardiopulmonary resuscitation, or CPR, does not often work to save the lives of those whose hearts have stopped outside of a hospital, and that it works less often on the elderly. Photo (M)
docs.snippet: The New Old AgePaula Span posted to  nytimes.com/newoldage :

headline.main: Baby Boomers Urged to Get Hepatitis C Test
headline.print_headline: Vital Signs | Screening: Baby Boomers Urged to Get Hepatitis C Test

docs.abstract: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended last week that all Americans born from 1945 through 1965 get a one-time hepatitis C test.
docs.snippet: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended last week that all Americans born from 1945 through 1965 get a one-time hepatitis C test.

docs.lead_paragraph: KRAUSHAR--Marvin F., M.D., F.I.C.S., of Newark, NJ, Westhampton Beach, NY and Palm Beach, Fla. passed away on Thursday, August 16 at the age of 74. Services will be held Wednesday, August 22 at Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, New Jersey at 11:00am. Dr. Kraushar grew up in Brooklyn, NY. A graduate of Poly Prep Country Day School, Bowdoin College and Tufts University School of Medicine. After his residency in ophthalmology, Dr. Kraushar completed a fellowship in medical and surgical diseases of the retina at Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary, Harvard Medical School. He served two years as a surgeon in the U.S. Public Health Service, attaining the rank of Lieutenant Commander. Dr. Kraushar was Chief of Ophthalmology at Beth Israel Medical Center and the Interfaith Medical Center in New York City. He was a Clinical Professor of opthalmology at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, Associate Clinical Professor of Ophthalmology at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine. He was an attending physician in opthalmology at St. Barnabas and Overlook Hospitals and was Director of the Retina Center of New Jersey. Dr. Kraushar served as the eye surgeon for the New Jersey Devils. Dr. Kraushar is survived by his loving wife, Gaytha Iuliano Kraushar. Donations in his memory may be made to The Seeing Eye, Inc., Morristown, NJ 07960, where he served as Trustee.

docs.lead_paragraph: Extreme poverty in the United States is giving rise to a group of infections known as the neglected tropical diseases, which we ordinarily think of as confined to developing countries.

headline.main: Tropical Diseases: The New Plague of Poverty
headline.print_headline: Tropical Diseases: The New Plague of Poverty

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Peter J Hotez, dean of the National School of Tropical Medicine at Baylor College, warns that one of the most tragic tolls of poverty is its tight link with a group of infections known as the neglected tropical diseases, which are typically though of as confined to developing countries; offers suggestions for addressing the problem.
docs.snippet: Extreme poverty in the United States is giving rise to a group of infections known as the neglected tropical diseases, which we ordinarily think of as confined to developing countries.

docs.lead_paragraph: A young woman feels dizzy and short of breath while vacationing with her family at the beach, and feels that her heart is beating irregularly.
